html:
Alternative forms[edit]

  • adprehendō
  • apprendō

Etymology[edit]

From ad- (“to, towards, at”) +‎ prehendō (“lay hold of, seize”).

Pronunciation[edit]

  • (Classical) IPA(key): /ap.preˈhen.doː/, [ap.prɛˈhɛn̪.d̪oː]
  • (Ecclesiastical) IPA(key): /ap.preˈen.do/, [ap.prɛˈɛn̪.d̪ɔ]

Verb[edit]

apprehendō (present infinitive apprehendere, perfect active apprehendī, supine apprehēnsum); third conjugation

  1. I lay hold upon, grasp, seize, grab, take, take hold of; apprehend, arrest.
  2. I grasp with the mind, understand, comprehend.
  3. I embrace, include.
  4. I take possession of, seize, secure, obtain.
  5. (Medieval Latin) I learn.

Derived terms[edit]

  • apprehēnsibilis
  • apprehēnsiō

Related terms[edit]

  • comprehendō
  • dēprehendō
  • prehendō
  • reprehendō

Descendants[edit]

  • Aromanian: aprindu, aprindiri
  • Asturian: aprender
  • Bourguignon: aiprarre
  • → aprehendre
  • → English: apprehend
  • Franco-Provençal: aprendre; → aprèhendar
  • Old French: aprendre
    • French: apprendre
    • Norman: apprendre
    • Walloon: aprinde
  • → Old French: apprehender
    • French: appréhender
    • → English: apprehend
  • → Galician: aprehender
  • Italian: apprendere
  • Old Occitan: aprendre
    • Catalan: aprendre
    • Occitan:
      Gascon: apréner
      Languedocien: aprendre
  • Old Portuguese: aprender
    • Galician: aprender
    • Portuguese: aprender
  • → Portuguese: apreender
  • Romanian: aprinde, aprindere; → aprehenda
  • Sicilian: apprènniri
  • Spanish: aprender; → aprehender

References[edit]

  • apprehendo in Charles du Fresne du Cange’s Glossarium Mediæ et Infimæ Latinitatis (augmented edition, 1883–1887)
  • apprehendo in Charlton T. Lewis and Charles Short (1879) A Latin Dictionary, Oxford: Clarendon Press
  • apprehendo in Charlton T. Lewis (1891) An Elementary Latin Dictionary, New York: Harper & Brothers
  • apprehendo in Gaffiot, Félix (1934) Dictionnaire Illustré Latin-Français, Hachette
